head.title: Bubbling and bistability in two parameter discrete systems

article.h1: Bubbling and bistability in two parameter discrete systems

span.span:
G Ambika and Sujatha N V
Department of Physics
Maharajas College
Cochin-682 011
INDIA.

div.p: We present a graphical analysis of the mechanisms underlying the occurrences of bubbling sequences and bistability regions in the bifurcation scenario of a special class of one dimensional two parameter maps. The main result of the analysis is that whether it is bubbling or bistability is decided by the sign of the third derivative at the inflection point of the map function.

1. Introduction.
The studies related to onset of chaos in one- dimensional discrete systems modeled by nonlinear maps, have been quite intense and exhaustive during the last two decades. Such a system normally supports a sequence of period doublings leading to chaos. It is also possible to take it back to periodicity through a sequence of period halvings by adding perturbations or modulations to the original system[1,2]. This has, most often, been reported as a mechanism for control of chaos. In addition, there are features like tangent bifurcations, intermittency, crises etc., that occur inside the chaotic regime and are not of immediate relevance to the present work. However, if the system is sufficiently nonlinear, there are other interesting phenomena like bubble structures and bistability that have invited comparatively less attention. The simplest cases where these are realised are maps with at least two control parameters, one that controls the nonlinearity and the other which is a constant additive one. i.e., maps of the type,

semantics.annotation: italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-f OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-b

div.p:
In these maps, if a𝑎italic-aa is varied for a given b𝑏italic-bb, the usual period doubling route to chaos is observed. But when a𝑎italic-aa is kept at a point beyond the first period doubling point a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, and b𝑏italic-bb is varied, the first period doubling is followed by a period halving forming a closed loop like structure called the primary bubble in the bifurcation diagram(Fig(1.a)). If a𝑎italic-aa is kept beyond the second bifurcation point a2subscript𝑎2italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{2}, and b𝑏italic-bb is tuned, secondary bubbles appear on the arms of the primary bubble. Thus as we shift the map along the a𝑎italic-aa-axis and drift it along the b𝑏italic-bb-axis, the complete bubbling scenario develops in the different slices of the space (X,a,b)𝑋𝑎𝑏OPEN:( italic-X PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)(X,a,b). This accumulates into what is known as bimodal chaos- chaos restricted or confined to the arms of the primary bubble. This can be viewed as a separate scenario to chaos in such systems.
It has been confirmed that the Feigenbaum indices for this scenario with a𝑎italic-aa as control parameter would be the same as the α𝛼italic-alpha\alpha and δ𝛿italic-delta\delta of the normal period doubling route to chaos[3]. However, detailed RG analysis by Oppo and Politi[4], involving the parameter b𝑏italic-bb also, indicates that if b𝑏italic-bb is kept at a critical value, bcsubscript𝑏𝑐italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{c}, where bimodal chaos just disappears, then there is a slowing down in the convergence rate leading to an index which is (δ)1/2superscript𝛿12OPEN:( italic-delta CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(\delta)^{1/2}. This has been experimentally verified in a C⁢O2𝐶subscript𝑂2italic-C italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endCO_{2} laser system with modulated losses[5]. The bubbling scenario is seen in the bifurcation diagrams of many nonlinear systems like coupled driven oscillators[6, 7], oscillatory chemical reactions, diode circuits, lasers[8,9], insect populations[10], cardiac cell simulations[11], coupled or modulated maps[12,13], quasi-periodically forced systems[14], DPCM transmission system[15] and traffic flow systems[16] etc. The very fact that this phenomenon appears in such a wide variety of systems makes it highly relevant to investigate and expose the common factor(s) in them i.e., the underlying basic features that make them support bubbles in their bifurcation scenario. The above mentioned continuous systems require maps with at least two parameters of type (1) to model them, the second additive parameter being the coupling strength, secondary forcing amplitude etc. We note that in all the above referred papers no specific mention is made regarding the mechanism of formation of bubbles, probably because the authors were addressing other aspects of the problem. However, there have been a number of isolated attempts to analyse the criteria for bubble formation in a few typical systems. According to Bier and Bountis[3], the two criteria are, the map must possess some symmetry and the first period doubling should occur facing the symmetry line. Later, Stone[17] makes these a little more explicit by stating that the map should have an extending tail (with a consequent inflection point) and the inflection point should occur to the right of the critical point of the map. It is clear that this applies only to maps with one critical point. The relation of the extending tail to bubbling is briefly discussed in [18] also.
Bistability is an equally interesting and common feature associated with many nonlinear systems like a ring laser[19] and a variety of electronic circuits[20] .A recent renewal of interest in such systems arises from the fact that they form ideal candidates for studies related to stochastic resonance phenomena[21]. The bistable behaviour in two parameter maps is shown in the bifurcation diagram in Fig(1.b). To the best of our knowledge, attempts to study any type of conditions for the occurrence of bistability are so far not seen reported in the literature.
Our motivation in the present work is to generalise the criteria reported earlier for bubbling and put them together with more clarity and simplicity. As a byproduct, we succeed in stating the conditions for bistability also along similar lines in systems of type (1), even though these are two mutually exclusive phenomena as far as their occurrence regime is concerned. We provide a detailed graphical analysis, which leads to a simple and comprehensible explanation for the same.
The paper is organized as follows. In section 2, the criteria for bistability and bubbling are stated followed by a brief explanation. The graphical analysis taking two simple cubic maps as examples is included in section 3 and the concluding comments in section 4.

2. The dynamics of bubbling and bistability
For the special class of maps given in (1), the basic criteria for bubbling / bistability can be stated as follows.
The non-linearity in f⁢(X,a,b)𝑓𝑋𝑎𝑏italic-f OPEN:( italic-X PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)f(X,a,b) must be more than quadratic.
This implies that, f′⁢(X,a,b)superscript𝑓′𝑋𝑎𝑏italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X,a,b) (the prime indicating derivative with respect to X𝑋italic-XX), is non-monotonic in X𝑋italic-XX and there exists at least one inflection point Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, where

semantics.annotation: italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PERIOD:.

div.p:
Then we consider the following two cases.
Case (i)

semantics.annotation: italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0

div.p: We define a value of a𝑎italic-aa as a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, through the relation,

semantics.annotation: italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 PUNCT:,

div.p:
the first period doubling point of the system. For a value of a𝑎italic-aa close to a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} but greater than a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, by adjusting the additive parameter b𝑏italic-bb, the system can be taken through a bubble structure in the bifurcation scenario.
Case (ii)

semantics.annotation: italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0

div.p: Here a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} is defined as the tangent bifurcation point of the system, through the relation

semantics.annotation: italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1

div.p:
Then by fixing a𝑎italic-aa greater than a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, but close to a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, and tuning b𝑏italic-bb, a bistability region can be produced in the system.
For case (i), the value of a𝑎italic-aa chosen to be greater than a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} makes f′⁢(Xi,a,b)<-1superscript𝑓′subscript𝑋𝑖𝑎𝑏1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{i},a,b)<-1 or |f′⁢(Xi,a,b)|>1superscript𝑓′subscript𝑋𝑖𝑎𝑏1VERTBAR:| italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1\left|f\ ^{\prime}(X_{i},a,b)\right|>1. Moreover, conditions (2) and (3) imply that Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i} is a minimum for f′superscript𝑓′italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\ ^{\prime}, which is concave upwards on both sides of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}. Hence for a fixed point X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} which is to the left of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, but in the immediate neighborhood, of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, |f′⁢(X-*,a,b)|<1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑎𝑏1VERTBAR:| italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\left|f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*},a,b)\right|<1, and hence will be stable.Similarly, fixed point X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} to the right of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, but near to Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, |f′⁢(X+*,a,b)|<1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑎𝑏1VERTBAR:| italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\left|f\ ^{\prime}(X_{+}^{*},a,b)\right|<1 and is stable. Now, the second parameter b𝑏italic-bb is simple additive for the class of maps under consideration and hence f′superscript𝑓′italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\ ^{\prime} is independent of b𝑏italic-bb. By adjusting b𝑏italic-bb, the fixed point can be shifted such that f′⁢(X-*,a,b)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑎𝑏italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*},a,b) becomes equal to -1, the period doubling point of the map.Then X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} will give rise to a 2-cycle with elements X1*superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{1}^{*} and X2*superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{2}^{*}. Since these are in the neighborhood of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, f′⁢(X1*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{1}^{*}) and f′⁢(X2*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{2}^{*}) will be negative so that the product f′⁢(X1*)⁢f′⁢(X2*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{1}^{*})f\ ^{\prime}(X_{2}^{*}) is positive. With further increase of b𝑏italic-bb, a𝑎italic-aa period merging takes place for the 2-cycle, with X1*superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{1}^{*} and X2*superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{2}^{*} collapsing into X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*}, which is just stable at the point where f′⁢(X+*)=-1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{+}^{*})=-1. Thus in the parameter window (b1,b2)subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2OPEN:( italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(b_{1},b_{2}), a bubble structure is formed.
The situation is exactly reversed for case (ii). Here conditions (2) and (5) makes Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i} a maximum of f′superscript𝑓′italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\,^{\prime} and the falls off on both sides of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}. At a value of a>a1𝑎subscript𝑎1italic-a RELOP:greater-than italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda>a_{1}, where a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} is defined by (6), f′⁢(Xi,a,b)>+1superscript𝑓′subscript𝑋𝑖𝑎𝑏1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{i},a,b)>+1. Then in the neighborhood of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, a fixed point X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*}, to the left of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, can be stable since |f′⁢(Xi,a,b)|<1superscript𝑓′subscript𝑋𝑖𝑎𝑏1VERTBAR:| italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\left|f\ ^{\prime}(X_{i},a,b)\right|<1. Similarly X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} on the right of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i} also will be stable.By adjusting the second parameter b𝑏italic-bb, these will be shifted to their respective tangent bifurcation points, i.e., b1subscript𝑏1italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1} where X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} is born and b2subscript𝑏2italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{2} where X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} disappears. Then a bistability window is seen in the interval (b1,b2)subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2OPEN:( italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(b_{1},b_{2}).
3. Graphical analysis.
The mechanism of occurrence of bubbling and bistability explained above for maps satisfying the conditions in case (i) and case (ii) respectively can be made more transparent through a detailed graphical analysis. For this we plot the curve C1=f′⁢(X)superscript𝑓′𝑋italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X), the 1-cycle fixed point curve C2=f⁢(X)-X𝑓𝑋𝑋italic-f OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-X{f(X)-X} and the 2-cycle curve C3=f⁢(f⁢(X))-X𝑓𝑓𝑋𝑋italic-f OPEN:( italic-f OPEN:( italic-X CLOSE:) CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-X{f(f(X))-X} simultaneously as functions of X𝑋italic-XX, for chosen values of a𝑎italic-aa and b𝑏italic-bb. The zeroes of C2 give the 1-cycle fixed point X*superscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX^{*} while those of C3 give the elements of the 2-cycle. Their stability can be checked from the same graph, since the value of the derivative at the fixed points can be read off. We fix the value of a𝑎italic-aa to be greater than a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, which helps to position the curve C1 in the proper way. By plotting the three curves for different values of b𝑏italic-bb, bistability regions or bubbling sequences can be traced for any given map function of type (1).
For further discussion, we consider two specific forms of maps of the cubic type, which are simple but typical examples for case (i) and (ii). They are,

semantics.annotation: italic-M NUMBER:1 METARELOP:colon italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-b ADDOP:minus italic-a italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

italic-M NUMBER:2 METARELOP:colon italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-b ADDOP:plus italic-a italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p:
For M1, there are two critical points, Xc⁢1=-a/3subscript𝑋𝑐1𝑎3italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-a MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 ARG:endX_{c1}=-\sqrt{a/3}, which is a maximum and Xc⁢2=a/3subscript𝑋𝑐2𝑎3italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start italic-a MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 ARG:endX_{c2}=\sqrt{a/3}, which is a minimum. The inflection point in between occurs at Xi=0subscript𝑋𝑖0italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0X_{i}=0 and f′′′=6superscript𝑓′′′6italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:6f\ ^{\prime\prime\prime}=6. Hence it belongs to case (i) and a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} as defined by (4) is 1. In Fig(2), the three curves mentioned above are plotted for this map at a=1.3𝑎1.3italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.3a=1.3. We start from a value of b=-1.34𝑏1.34italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.34b=-1.34, Fig(2.a) where the fixed point X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} is just born via tangent bifurcation since f′⁢(X-*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*}) here is +1, and the curves C2 and C3 just touches the zero line on the left of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i} at X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*}. Though C2 has a zero on the right, the slope there is larger than 1 and hence it is unstable, for this value of b𝑏italic-bb. Since b𝑏italic-bb is only additive, increase in the value of b𝑏italic-bb, shifts C2 upwards, resulting in a slow drift of X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} from left to right. Thus as b𝑏italic-bb is increased to -0.7(Fig(2.b)), f′⁢(X-*)=-1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*})=-1 and X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} bifurcates into X1*superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{1}^{*} and X2*superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{2}^{*}. At b=-0.3𝑏0.3italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.3b=-0.3(Fig(2.c)), the 2-cycle is stable with f′⁢(X1*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{1}^{*}) and f′⁢(X2*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{2}^{*}), both negative and their product is positive but less than 1. Note that the curve C3 has developed a maximum and a minimum on both sides of X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*}, which is now unstable, cutting the zero line again at X1*<X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋1superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{1}^{*}<X_{-}^{*} and X2*>X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋2superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{2}^{*}>X_{-}^{*}. As b𝑏italic-bb is further increased, they move apart. Since the value chosen is within the stability window of 2-cycle no further period doubling takes place. As X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} crosses Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}, X1*superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{1}^{*} &ADDOP:and\& X2*superscriptsubscript𝑋2italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{2}^{*} move towards each other and merge together at b=0.7𝑏0.7italic-b RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7b=0.7(Fig(2.d)) and coincide with the fixed point X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*}. Further, X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} disappears by a reverse tangent bifurcation at b=1.34𝑏1.34italic-b RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.34b=1.34, when f′⁢(X+*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{+}^{*}) becomes equal to +1. Thus the above events lead to the formation of a primary bubble in the window (-0.7,0.7).
By keeping a𝑎italic-aa at a value beyond the second period doubling point a2subscript𝑎2italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{2}, of the map, the merging tendency starts only after the second period doubling and hence secondary bubbles are seen on the arms of the primary bubble. These can be repeated until at a>a∞𝑎subscript𝑎italic-a RELOP:greater-than italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda>a_{\infty}, the system is taken to chaos.
Now the above analysis is repeated for map M2, which satisfies the conditions in case (ii) (Fig(3)). Here of the two critical points of the map, Xc⁢1=-a/3subscript𝑋𝑐1𝑎3italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-square-root ARG:start italic-a MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 ARG:endX_{c1}=-\sqrt{a/3} is the minimum and Xc⁢2=a/3subscript𝑋𝑐2𝑎3italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-square-root ARG:start italic-a MULOP:divide NUMBER:3 ARG:endX_{c2}=\sqrt{a/3} is the maximum with a positive slope at the point of inflection Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}. a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} in this case is also 1. Hence in the Fig (3) a𝑎italic-aa is chosen to be 1.4. Fig(3.a) shows the situation for b=-0.35𝑏0.35italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.35b=-0.35, where f′⁢(X*)=-1superscript𝑓′superscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X^{*})=-1 and hence the 1-cycle fixed point X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} period doubles into a 2-cycle. For lower values of b𝑏italic-bb, we expect the full period doubling scenario since f′superscript𝑓′italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\ ^{\prime} is monotonic beyond this point(Fig(3.b)). However, as b𝑏italic-bb is increased to -0.1, f′⁢(X+*)=+1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{+}^{*})=+1, where the other 1-cycle, X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} to the right of Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i} is born by tangent bifurcation(Fig(3.c)). Note that at this point X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} is still stable with |f′⁢(X-*)|<1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1VERTBAR:| italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1\left|{f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*})}\right|<1. This continues until b=+0.1𝑏0.1italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.1b=+0.1, where f′⁢(X-*)=+1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*})=+1 and hence X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} disappears(Fig(3.d)). The birth of X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} is concurrent with the maximum of C2 touching the zero line (b=b1)𝑏subscript𝑏1OPEN:( italic-b RELOP:equals italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(b=b_{1}) while the disappearance of X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} occurs as the minimum of C2 touches the zero line (b=b2)𝑏subscript𝑏2OPEN:( italic-b RELOP:equals italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(b=b_{2}). As b𝑏italic-bb is increased and C2 is moving up it is clear that the former will take place for a lower b𝑏italic-bb value than the latter as the maximum of C2 occurs for X>Xi𝑋subscript𝑋𝑖italic-X RELOP:greater-than italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX>X_{i} and minimum at X<Xi𝑋subscript𝑋𝑖italic-X RELOP:less-than italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX<X_{i} (slope being positive at Xisubscript𝑋𝑖italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endX_{i}). Hence b1<b2subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endb_{1}<b_{2}, or there is a window (b1,b2)subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2OPEN:( italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(b_{1},b_{2}), where bistability exists, which in our graph is (-0.1,0.1) for a=1.4𝑎1.4italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.4a=1.4. X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} is stable beyond this point also and it period doubles as b𝑏italic-bb is increased to b=+0.35𝑏0.35italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.35b=+0.35 where f′⁢(X+*)=-1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{+}^{*})=-1. The full Feigenbaum scenario then develops for higher values of b𝑏italic-bb.By keeping a𝑎italic-aa at higher values and tuning b𝑏italic-bb, the bistability can be taken to 2-cycle, 4-cycle and even chaotic regions.
The stability regions of the different types of dynamical behaviour possible for M1 can be marked out in parameter space plot in the (a,b)𝑎𝑏OPEN:( italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)(a,b) plane(Fig(4.a)). The cone like region on the left is the stability zone of the 1-cycle fixed point (periodicity, p=1) and it is separated from the escape region by the tangent bifurcation line on both sides. The parabola like curve inside it marks out the 2-cycle (p=2) region, while the smaller parabolas indicate curves along which 4-cycles (p=4) and other higher periodic cycles becomes stable until chaos is reached. The line parallel to the b𝑏italic-bb-axis at a value of a>a1𝑎subscript𝑎1italic-a RELOP:greater-than italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda>a_{1}, along which primary bubble is formed, is shown by the dotted line. It is clear that along this line, the system is taken from escape –¿ 1-cycle –¿2-cycle –¿1-cycle –¿ escape. Similarly secondary bubbles are formed along a line drawn at a>a2𝑎subscript𝑎2italic-a RELOP:greater-than italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda>a_{2} etc. The parameter space plot for M2 is shown in Fig(4.b). The quadrilateral like region marked as (I) beyond a>a1𝑎subscript𝑎1italic-a RELOP:greater-than italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda>a_{1} is the bistable region for 1-cycle, while quadrilateral (II) is that for 2-cycle etc. The area marked with p=1, is the stability region of 1-cycle while p=2, that for 2-cycle etc. When the system is taken along the dotted line beyond a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1}, bistability is seen in the central region, followed by period doubling bifurcations to both sides, until chaos is reached.
4. Conclusion.
Although the above discussion is confined to two simple cubic maps, the analysis is repeated for a large number of maps of type (1) chosen from a wide variety of situations covering different functional forms like exponential, trigonometric and polynomial maps. We find that the qualitative behaviour in all cases remain the same and depends only on the criteria (2)-(6). Hence the pattern of scenario detailed in this paper can be taken to be atypical as far as maps of the form (1) are concerned.
The criteria for bistability reported here are certainly novel while those for bubbling are more rigorous and general in nature compared to earlier studies. They can be used as a test to identify maps in which bistability or bubbling is possible and also to isolate the regions in the parameter space (a,b)𝑎𝑏OPEN:( italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)(a,b) where they occur. Our main result is that whether it is bistability or bubbling is decided by the sign of the third derivative of the map function at the inflection point. If f′′′⁢(Xi)superscript𝑓′′′subscript𝑋𝑖italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime\prime\prime}(X_{i}) is positive, because of the concave nature of the derivative, tangent bifurcation will precede period doubling as b𝑏italic-bb is increased. Hence bubbling structure is possible. Similarly when f′′′⁢(Xi)superscript𝑓′′′subscript𝑋𝑖italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime\prime\prime}(X_{i}) is negative, curve of f′superscript𝑓′italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endf\ ^{\prime} is convex and hence period doubling precedes tangent bifurcation, leading to bistability. In case f′′′⁢(Xi)=0superscript𝑓′′′subscript𝑋𝑖0italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0f\ ^{\prime\prime\prime}(X_{i})=0, higher derivatives must be considered for deciding the behaviour.
Bubbling can be looked upon as an extreme case of incomplete period doublings and the latter has been often associated with positive Schwarzian derivative[22]. But for the system under study, it is easy to check that this is always negative (independent of the form of the map function), because of properties (2), (3) and (5). In fact, a few such maps have been reported earlier[23] though in a totally different context. The bubbling scenario in maps of the type M1, leads to bimodal chaos that is restricted to the arms of the primary bubble. Such confined chaos or even low periodic behavior prior to that, makes them better models in population dynamics of eco systems than the usual logistic type maps[24]. Attempts to extend the criteria to continuous and higher dimensional systems are underway and will be reported elsewhere.

Fig.3:- Here the curves C1 ,C2 and C3 for the map M2 defined in (8) with a=1.4𝑎1.4italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.4a=1.4 plotted. (a) At b=-0.5𝑏0.5italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.5b=-0.5, it is clear from the figure that the 1-cycle solution is unstable and the 2-cycle is stable. (b) b=-0.35𝑏0.35italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.35b=-0.35 gives the first period doubling point i.e., here f′⁢(X-*)=-1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*})=-1. (c) At b=b1=-0.1𝑏subscript𝑏10.1italic-b RELOP:equals italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.1b=b_{1}=-0.1, f′⁢(X+*)=+1superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋1italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1f\ ^{\prime}(X_{+}^{*})=+1, i.e., the creation of a new fixed point X+*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{+}^{*} by tangent bifurcation. Note that still X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} is stable and (d) b=b2=0.1𝑏subscript𝑏20.1italic-b RELOP:equals italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1b=b_{2}=0.1, f′⁢(X-*)superscript𝑓′superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-f POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)f\ ^{\prime}(X_{-}^{*}) is +1. Hence the existing fixed point X-*superscriptsubscript𝑋italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endX_{-}^{*} disappears. Thus (b1,b2)subscript𝑏1subscript𝑏2OPEN:( italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-b POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(b_{1},b_{2}) gives the bistability window.
Fig.4:- Parameter space plot in (a,b)𝑎𝑏OPEN:( italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)(a,b) plane (a) for map M1 and (b) for map M2.
